TEXT.English: "Falamar..." Chaeli whispered.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]He pushed her against one of the massive crates that littered the docks of Dunwich. The moon was well past its zenith and the narrow gap between two crates where they found themselves was hidden in shadows. It was a beautiful night, but the stink of the docks hung thick in the air.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]She leaned back as his kisses wandered down her neck to her very ample bosom. Only stopping when she playfully pulled his hands away when they reached inside her bodice.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Ain't ya ever wanted to be with the legendary Falamar?" he asked and she smiled radiantly, letting him grope her until he began pulling up on her dress.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"No, no," she said, "just kiss me."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]There was a second of anger in his eyes, even in her drunken haze Chaeli recognized it, she had seen it before from other men and it never ended well.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]He kissed her again, raising her hands above her head where he held both with one of his hands. He held them so tightly they felt like they were manacled to the wall. His other hand reached down and pulled up her dress, tearing it aside and reaching hungrily into it.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"No, Falamar," she yelled. Then when he wouldn't stop she bit his cheek.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]He let go of his dress and punched her full in the face, her head crunched against the wooden crate and seagulls along the dock yelled in complaint and took to flight. She started crying as he reached again for her dress.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Did someone call me?" A man standing a the edge of the crates asked.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The attacker, the man pretending to be Falamar, quickly let go of Chaeli and stepped away from the speaker. The speaker was a thin handsome man, lean and confident though he looked dangerous now, like a coiled snake. Though Chaeli felt unthreatened by him, her attacker felt differently and he immediately let go of Chaeli.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Captain Falamar," he stammered.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Issac?" Falamar answered, "I was sure I heard my name."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Falamar, the real Falamar, kept advancing into the makeshift alley between the crates and Issac kept backing up. When Falamar reached Chaeli he asked her, "Are you okay?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]She nodded and tried to wipe the tears from her eyes. She could already feel her face bruising up from the punch.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I'm sorry Falamar," Issac said, "sometimes I tell the gullie's I'm you. Just a bit of wishful dreaming I suppose."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"That is not the crime I am concerned about." Falamar answered. Then Falamar struck, jumping forward he caught the larger man by the collar and slammed him back against the crates. Issac drew his knife but Falamar knocked it easily aside. With Issac trapped against the crate Falamar punched him, splintering Issac's cheekbone so severely it left his left eye rolling loosely in its socket and his cheek ran flush with purple blood.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Go or I will give my sword to the lady and she will act out her desires on you, as you had intended for her."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Issac scrambled away.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Chaeli, stunned into silence until this moment, fell suddenly into uncontrollable tears. Falamar tilted up her face, checking her bruise and as her sobs quieted her gave her a slight smile.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Can I walk you home?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Chaeli only nodded in response. They walked in silence through the empty streets. Despite the trauma it was still a beautiful night and as they approached the squat flat Chaeli shared with her family she finally spoke.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I thought... he said he was you."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Falamar waited until they stood before her door before he answered.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"You deserve better than the Dunwich docks. Expect more from men, no matter their name."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]She nodded, not really understanding.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Will you be okay?" Falamar asked.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Yes, my father is home. I will be okay, thanks to you."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Falamar gave her another slight smile, said good night and headed back toward the docks. They were supposed to have set sail hours ago but Falamar was late as usual. He arrived to find the ship and the crew ready. Several men traded knowing glances as he came aboard.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"What was her name this time captain?" one called.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I didn't ask." Falamar responded.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]His men laughed and cheered, they all assumed incorrectly but it boosted their spirits and Falamar saw little harm in it. The legend was certainly greater than the man, but when you regularly asked your men to face death sometimes it was easier if they believed a legend led them.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Amergin, Falamar's first mate, had already loaded the supplies and made sure the crew was on board and relatively sober. He had questions but had been serving Falamar since they were both boys, so he knew he would get the answers when Falamar was ready.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Yes Amergin, we will be sailing out by moonlight. I have a contract from a Balseraph princess and it seems we need to make up some time. She pays well, and needs us to trap some animals for her."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Its an unusual task for you," Amergin commented.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Easy gold and a damsel who needs help. It sounds exactly like me."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Amergin smiled and ordered the crew to lift the anchor and set sail. Within seconds the ship was off to the Aegis Isles.
Keelyn giggles gleefully at the caged animals and construction of the upcoming Grand Menagerie. "This is wonderful," she squeals, "fetch me one of those big grey teethy beasts!"
TEXT.German: Keelyn kichert schadenfroh über die gefangenen Tiere und die Errichtung der baldigen Großen Menagerie. "Das ist wunderbar", kreischt sie. "Fangt mir eines dieser großen grauen Bestien mit Zähnen!"

TEXT.English: Keelyn stares in amazement at the captured elephant. "I've heard of another pet, a chicken cat. Get one of those for me too!"
TEXT.German: Keelyn starrt voller Verwunderung auf den gefangenen Elefanten. "Ich habe von einem weiteren Tierchen gehört, einem Katzen-Huhn. Bringt mir auch eines davon!"

TEXT.English: She was a delightful, if not demented, child and she twirled and danced between the animals we had assembled for her. Her courtier counted out the gold we had been promised and excused her behavior, though it was his disdain for her that bothered me far more than the young princess's enthusiasm.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]After checking each animal Keelyn approached me. She had a griffon feather in her hair and her dress, though once beautiful, was now patched and worn as if unable to keep up with the tiny tornado.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"These must be the most excellent animals from anywhere on Erebus!"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]I smiled, "I am pleased that you think so, my hunters searched every corner of this island to find them for you. Where other princesses have rooms of toy animals, you will have the real things."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]She grinned. This was my plan, to keep her focused on how wonderful it was. Her mind didn't dwell long on achievements and she was usually racing off to the next goal, and I had tired of searching this island for whatever she wanted next. But it was too late, her smile faded and her brow furrowed in thought. She was going to ask for more.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"It is a wonderful collection, but what about those that don't live on the island? What about those in the sea? The Lanun are talented fishermen, right?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"The best," I answered, at least this was the sort of hunting my men would prefer, "would you like us to gather some giant crabs, otolochs, or tortoises for you?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]She seemed to consider the suggestion, "No" she said, "do you know the giant wiggly beasts that are painted on the walls of the temple in Shaol?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Yes, squids. They wouldn't survive long in your zoo I'm afraid. They had to stay in the water."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Keelyn nodded, "Bring me some and I'll have Chuckles close in the harbor so they can't run away."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Occasionally we caught squid in our nets, from those as long as a man's arm to those twice as long as a man. It wouldn't be much trouble to snare a few for her.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Of course," I said loud enough for her snobbish courtier to hear, "we would be happy to capture a few squid for your collection, for the same price as the others."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The courtier sighed and looked as disappointed as Keelyn was excited.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Load up the ships," I called to the men, "we do the rest of our hunting from beneath the white and purple, and atop a hull full of rum."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]My men cheered and a few hours later we set out from the docks with a fair wind and high spirits.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]I dropped into darkness. I could hear the explosion of splintering wood and sense the movement of a giant around me. Something so great even the whales feared it. The central mast broke and plunged past me through the water. This was the only indication I had of direction, and I began swimming desperately toward the direction the mast came from.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The seas were rough, but the Lanun like to say that just requires more drink to steady the ship. Though it was the perfect area for fishing our nets came up empty on every pull. We were preparing to move back towards the coast when the creatures attacked.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Giant tentacles reached up over the deck and crushed the ships as if they were made of paper. There was no coherent defense against this attack and the screaming of my men disappeared as the sea claimed me.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Just as I saw the shimmer of light through the inky darkness, as my lungs burned for air, I felt the tip of a tentacle close around my leg. I reached for my sword, but the sheath was empty. I had lost it in the water. A tug pulled me down, away from that golden halo of light and I fought for any way out of its grip.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]There was a single glint of metal in the darkness. It floated down from the remains of the ship and I reached to catch it. It was beyond my reach so I twisted against the tentacle, buying myself a precious few inches and I closed my hand around it. I immediately twisted back into the tentacle bringing the weapon to cut it from my leg. Only to discover that I only held a silver candlestick. In that moment my lungs exploded and I drank in the sea. All else disappeared.
Into the Desert
TEXT.German: In die Wüste

TEXT.English: Flauros looks up as Decius and his troops enter the palace. "Ah, commander, how go our plans?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius crosses his arms. "I've tried things your way. This Empyrean religion is only gaining followers. It is time to be more aggressive."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"We have discussed why that is not among your options."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"This Varn Gosam has called a meeting of tribal leaders. My spies tell me they are leaning toward uniting with him. Your foes will hold much more power in this region unless we act to stop them. I will take your army to the Malakim capital and burn it to the ground. That should keep the sand rats in their place."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"You will act within the limits I have set for you. Or I will tear you to shreds."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius raised blade. "Can you do so before I get in a single hit?" Flauros laughed, drawing his own blade, but Decius continued, "Because the Council's assassins have shown me a few things. Such as a rare desert plant, the extracts of which can cause a man pain like he's never known for as long as he lives. Perhaps you are willing to chance that over the course of your very long life you can find an antidote. Or that the effects will wear off after only a few hundred years. But why not chance that your power can be used beyond playing shepherd to a broken people, can rather shape the world stage to our benefit?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Flauros stood a moment, gazing at Decius. Then he sheathed his blade. "My sister would have killed you, and lived with the pain. Very well, take what you need. Raze every city with the Empyrean. If you bring calamity upon us, I will survive, and you will not, no matter the trump you hold. If your gamble succeeds, you will have a place among us forever."

The primitive encampment of the Hill Giants is razed, and the Giants themselves feeding the vultures. In one hut dwell a score of human slaves, their eyes lighting up at the sight of the destruction of their captors. One young man in tattered yellow clothes approaches Decius. "In the name of Lugus the Light, I thank you sir."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Who is this Lugus? Your feudal lord?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Nay, good sir, he is the god of light, whose wisdom enlightens all the peoples of this desert."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius yanks the mans chains, pulling him to his knees. "Not wise enough to keep you safe, nor alert you when you speak to a foe." [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Flauros is pleased to see that Decius has the mettle he suspected. Less so to hear of the Ecclesiastic. "I have not seen a priest of Lugus for over six hundred years, and now one appears on my borders? This is an ill sign."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius raises an eyebrow. "Six hundred years? The Prelates spoke of devil-men living in the desert of Myrh. I hadn't expected they were being quite so literal."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I have no allegiance to Hell, simply similar tactics-extracting power from mortals. I trust this doesn't strain our working arrangement?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius shrugged. "I've little illusions about how you treat your subjects. What you do with their souls is even less my concern. I've passed your test. What is next?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"The Bannor were fools to discard such a useful tool as you. Efficient and heartless. But I need guile as well. Lugus is an old foe, and not one to release a grudge. His cult gaining ground here means trouble for us. I need you to strike down these Ecclesiastics, without drawing us into direct confrontation with the desert tribes."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I've seen your power. Give me command of a larger force of vampires and we can be ruling this entire desert."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I have shared our secret with you, Decius, but wish it to remain that. If we take ourselves into the battlefield, we will be hunted down by all the nations. Better to stay on the edges of the civilized world. Lugus has other enemies that may aid us, however, without asking questions. Let us encourage the Council of Esus among our lands, and train men who can strike without revealing their masters. Use them to eliminate the disciples of Lugus, and the power I wield may be yours."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Very well, we will do this your way, Flauros."

TEXT.English: An obese, pale man, carried on a litter by a slaves watches Decius training his units for the assault on Dirage. Decius walks over after organizing a scout patrol. "I don't suppose you've come to enlist," he says. The man has the clear signs of Calabim aristocracy, but Decius takes a measure of satisfaction from refusing to acknowledge it.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I am the governor of this city. Flauros decrees that I must cooperate with you, find out what you need to research for your task. It pleases him to give this authority to such as yourself, for reasons I couldn't grasp."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius thought for a moment. "If I am successful, I will have the cusp of an empire. Feudalism would be useful for this, though..." He glanced up at the governor, realizing he wanted more than to build an empire for lazy fools like these. Deception. Poison. Tools like these could help him in a conflict with his benefactor Flauros or other foes to come. Religion was a useful tool for controlling a nation, but he decided it would be a poor idea to invite such foreign influence and invite the eye of meddling goods.

Decius has fled the Bannor, seeking refuge across the sea. In the desert of Myrh dwell the Malakim, a morally upright people. He has had his fill of moral presumption, however, and seeks shelter amongst a more ethically flexible culture.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Calabim are an ancient order whose aristocracy prey on the weak of their society. Weakness has long since been drilled out of Decius.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]It is a blighted neighborhood on the outskirts of Prespur over which Decius has exerted influence. Between the battered humans who have had their wills broken and those petty thugs just strong enough to prey on them, he has no competition for the petty fiefdom he sets up, so long as the aristocrats do not deign to enter.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Flauros, second born of all vampires, has seen this play out many times before. It is a replay of the Calabim social structure on a smaller scale, and he delights in letting the local lord know who is really on top.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius knows he is playing a dangerous game. When the bloodpets of the Vampiric lord come, his army is alert and dispatches them promptly. Flauros himself, however, is harder to handle. He personally slays Decius's army of exiles and criminals, leaving the bodies for the Moroi. Decius himself is far too interesting to do in, however.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"We have few immigrants here, and fewer still with your skills. Why do you come to our land, only to wallow in the filth of the livestock?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius folds his arms. "I kept every code and rule of my home, only to have them turn me out. I am through with rules and submission to authority. I will rise to the top, or die on my feet."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Flauros smiled. "Whether you know it or not, you have come to the right place then. Our nation is a meritocracy in ways the Bannor would never hope to emulate. Those undeserving are consumed, while those who prove themselves are rewarded beyond their keen. I offer you a chance to start down this path. I will give you command of a small force. Eliminate the Hill Giants that have been preying on our countryside."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius nodded. "Very well. But with the rabble you call soldiers, I don't give good odds of my survival."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Either way it will be entertaining."

Decius earned a place among the Calabim through grit and guile, and has forced them to take a more competitive place among the nations of Erebus. Just as a competition is heating up on the other side of the desert of Myrh. Word comes through the Undercouncil of dark plans reaching fulfillment, as the Sheaim complete their masterstroke and unleash the Infernals into the world. This is not as the Calabim would have preferred, but does present opportunities. Flauros offers Decius the opportunity to see how best he can exploit this brutal war. The remnants of the Malakim have taken arms in defense of their friends, so Decius sets out in a fleet of ships to flank them on the foothills of Tempus Mor.
Description: Follow Decius as he flees into the desert.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Requires: Successful completion of the Fall of Cuantine scenario.
TEXT.German: Beschreibung: Verfolgt Decius auf seiner Flucht in die Wüste.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Belohnung: Der erfolgreiche Abschluss dieses Szenarios gewährt Zugang zum Szenario "Die gerechte Strafe".

TEXT.English: Varn was a difficult man to find in the weeks after his revelations. Decius came upon him sending out a group of messengers, and he turned to Decius to explain, "We can no longer tarry with the tribes of this desert. I will call a council meeting. A desert custom I hope to incorporate into the Overcouncil. Those that adopted our faith will join with us, but I fear we will alienate those that did not. Either way, your task has not changed, just expanded. You need to spread this faith throughout the region. It must become the dominant creed here for our alliance to last. Beware the Calabim, for they will surely continue to oppose us."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Varn turned to go, anxious to oversee some Vicar's training, or perhaps give guidance to a caravanner. Decius stopped him with a hand on his shoulder. "I am not sure I like this goal, Varn. My people were united by the Order of Junil, it is true, but I now see that their zeal was not without a grave price, a price I do not wish to extract in pursuit of your cause either."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Varn smiled. "The tactics are up to you, Decius. We need not seek destruction of the Calabim, wicked as they may be, if our missionaries are able in their persuasion, and likewise you can try to avoid bringing harm to those of the desert that oppose us. But the desert is a harsh place, and I need a man of steel like you that I can depend on. For your tactical mind, and for a friend who will voice his concerns should our task overwhelm my judgment. With haste, perhaps a band of Ecclesiastics will be enough. If not, the Vicars will be able to drive out competing creeds in our allied towns. Force is an allowable last resort, I'm afraid."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius nodded and let Varn leave.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"At least you got to speak to him today." Decius turned to see Talia, the beautiful woman who had first given him a role in the Malakim-and Varn Gosam's wife.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"My lady."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Always with his priests these days. His work is a noble mission, but I confess I was happier before Lugus's worship was so codified, and my wisdom was sought as well. By day he is in meeting after meeting, training missionaries and scribes and hearing disputes among his faithful, clarifying dogma. And by night... well I am ready for him, but he is so exhausted!"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I will speak to him of your concerns, then," Decius said, stepping back.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Thank you, Decius. You are a good friend, and like the Varn I love in so many ways." She gave him a kiss on each cheek before leaving him to his duty; a custom in the desert, though not a common one in this day. Decius steeled himself to his task. He had known countless women widowed by war, women with complaints that dwarfed Talia's, but her loneliness was genuine. The Varn she had pledged to was not the one so consumed with his goals... but such is life.

TEXT.English: Decius has fled his homeland after being charged with witchcraft and conjuring demons. He seeks to preserve his values and find a new beginning among the Malakim, across the seas in the desert of Myrh. This ancient tribal people is coalescing around an unlikely new spiritual leader-the elf Varn Gosam, a refugee from an isolated elven community.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Malakim have taken in Decius and his entourage; hospitality in the desert is an iron law. He has yet to see meet his host, however.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]While watching the young soldiers drill in the evening Decius is approached by a raven-haired woman flanked by a sand lion cub. Flowing robes keep the sun off her skin but do nothing to hide her figure as the wind blows them taut against her. "Welcome, stranger. You have the look of one who well knows the art these boys struggle to master."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I was a soldier of some renown, milady, and a commander for a season. I felled my people's enemies, until I was deemed one."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Strong and wise, and bereft of your heritage, like our Varn. We could make use of your skills, in exchange for a place of refuge."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"A gracious offer, milady. Have you the authority to make it?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"It is not authority I wield here, just influence, but I suspect it will be enough. More so if you could perform one task for us now. Varn Gosam has been gone for some time on pilgrimage, too long I fear. Lead a party to find him, east at the Mirror of Heaven, and you will have proven your worth and earned your place."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius rises with a nod. "I shall do so then. Who shall I say has commissioned this search?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The lady smiles. "My name is Talia."

The windswept dunes change gradually as Decius nears the holy site of the Malakim. Travel across the flat glass field is treacherous, but in the center, near a crystal clear pool is Varn Gosam. Amidst a warm glow, he stands and greets the stern man leading the Malakim soldiers.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"You must be Decius. I came here to seek further guidance from Lugus the Light, who led me from the Shadowed Vale in preparation for some task. It is good to see that the Malakim have taken you in, as they have me. They are a hospitable people, with a destiny far beyond the dunes. I have no doubt you can find your purpose among them."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius turned his eyes from the glowing water. "The Bannor's priesthood gave me a clear purpose as well, to fight evil and stamp out heresy. I served them well and was betrayed. I think for a time I am content with aimlessness."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Varn smiled. "This is a new day for you, Decius. Dawn comes, and it is no time for slumber. For any who love good and freedom, for Lugus has shown me a vision of evil stirring in a far-off land. We must prepare, must bind together all good peoples in one council house before it is too late. Will you help me spread this vision? First to our brethren tribes in this desert, and beyond, to the peoples of the Elohim, the Kuriotates, the Khazad, the Ljosalfar-and perhaps even to the Bannor as well?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I cannot turn on my ideals. If it is as you say, I will serve you and your cause, Gosam. Even if it means facing those who wrongly seek my head."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"And in return, you will never need do so alone. This is the message of the Empyrean." Varn Gosam loaded his belongings-incense, a water skin, a light tent, a pouch of salted meat-onto his camel. His tone changed as he and Decius headed back towards the awaiting Malakim party. "Lugus spoke to me of one other thing, Decius. The people to our East have a dread secret, and an ancient grudge with our good god. As we seek to spread our faith, I fear they will be an implacable foe, opposing us with sword and spell."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"This kind of opposition I am well suited for dealing with, Varn. Prepare your teachers, and I will guard them with our soldiers."

Decius has found a new home with the Malakim, and now leads Varn Gosam's quest to unite the good nations under an Overcouncil, to fight the prophesied resurgence of an ancient foe.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]But their success in the desert of Myrh is about to be tested. Messengers arrive from the Elohim, imploring their allies to come to their aid. The Sheaim, a secretive tribe west of the Elohim homelands, have uncovered a dark ritual, bringing the Archangel of Agares, Hyborem, into Erebus. He has emerged in the mountains of Tempus Mor leading an army of Infernals; from further west come tales of more demonic invasions. At the same time the Svartalfar have taken advantage of the situation to declare war on their rivals, restarting the elven war that had concluded when one queen perished years ago. Ethne the White warns that she is considering desperate action to preserve her people, and so Varn Gosam requests Decius bring the armies of the Malakim west, in an attempt to preserve the alliance of the Overcouncil and bring peace to Tempus Mor.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Though once betrayed by the Bannor, the skills they taught him will be put to the test.
Lord of the Balors
TEXT.German: Fürst der Balor

TEXT.English: During the Age of Ice men made sacrifices here in order to appease what they believed to be the gods beyond. In a world of permanent winter the burning lands beyond seemed like a twisted heaven to the primitive men of that age. But these "gods" demanded sacrifices from their worshippers that were often more costly than the cold.
TEXT.German: Während des Zeitalters des Eises brachten die Menschen hier Opfer dar, um jene zu besänftigen, die sie für die jenseitigen Götter hielten. In einer Welt des permanenten Winters erschienen die brennenden Lande des Jenseits den primitiven Menschen dieses Zeitalters wie eine verdrehte Version des Himmels. Aber diese "Götter" forderten Opfergaben von ihren Gläubigen, die oft kostspieliger als die Kälte waren.

TEXT.English: This altar is for the Lord of the Balors. The vast minions of hell sacrifice here in the hope of gaining some favor with Hyborem. Many generals have made it this far, but you are the first that wasn't carried here by demonic legions and sacrificed on the black and red stone.
TEXT.German: Dieser Altar ist dem Meister der Balor geweiht. Die vielen Lakaien der Hölle bringen hier ihre Opfer in der Hoffnung dar, eine kleine Gunst von Hyborem zu erhalten. Viele Generäle haben es bis hier geschafft, aber Ihr seid der erste, der nicht von den dämonischen Legionen hierher getragen und auf dem schwarz-roten Stein geopfert wurde.

TEXT.English: The Balseraphs stared at the distant city of Dis, more terrifying than anything even their fertile imaginations could have created. The pass is covered in dark monuments to Hyborem's countless achievements. The corpses of his foes are built into these monuments or scattered across the wastes as a warning to any who would seek to defeat him. The stenches of sulfur and rotting flesh mingle together, making the foulest slums of Jubilee seem like a paradise. And the dread metropolis of Dis itself rises above it all. None of the Balseraphs dare imagine how many damned souls toil in that wretched city, or how many of them are armed and ready to defend it, rather than risk displeasing their dread masters.[PARAGRAPH:1]"It smells funny," Keelyn says, "but it could be pretty with a new coat of paint. I'm thinking pink. Everything looks nicer in pink."
TEXT.German: Die Balseraph starrten auf die ferne Stadt Dis, die Furcht einflößender war, als sie es sich selbst mit ihrer lebhaften Vorstellungskraft hätten ausmalen können. Der Pass ist gespickt mit dunklen Monumenten für Hyborems zahllosen Taten. Die Leichen seiner Feinde sind in diese Monumente eingelassen oder über die Einöde verstreut, als Warnung für jene, die versuchen sollten, ihn zu besiegen. Der Gestank von Schwefel und verrotendem Fleisch vermischen sich und lassen den dreckigsten Slum von Jubilee wie ein Paradies erscheinen. Und die grauenvolle Metropole Dis selbst thront über allem. Keiner der Balseraph wagt sich auch nur vorzustellen, wieviele verdammte Seelen in dieser elenden Stadt gequält werden, oder wieviele davon bewaffnet und lieber bereit sind, sie zu verteidigen, als die Verärgerung ihrer Meister zu riskieren.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Es riecht komisch", sagt Keelyn, "aber es könnte mit einem neuen Anstrich ganz hübsch sein. Ich denke an Rosa. Alles sieht in Rosa schöner aus."

TEXT.English: The Mercurian men cheered. These were fierce, passionate men who viewed their lives as a temporary stage before their transform into the magnificent angels of Basium's army. They threw themselves fully into battle and marched unquestioning into the Fane of Lessers. Death in righteous battle was their hope. There was no such thing as an old Mercurian soldier.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The angels were more somber. The Seraphim with their blazing swords kept careful watch for more dangers, the Ophanim floated above the broken fields for the first time riding unhindered within the Fane and the Valkyries tended to the dead.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Basium stood before the Throne of Hell, a vast gaping hole in Erebus. The ground around it bled a thick, dark ichor. It was a physical wound in this world, fully contaminated and defiled. Through it hell could be seen, a vast mountain sloping ever down to dark swamps. Somewhere beyond that swamp Basium knew the foul city of Mammon sat. It was the first step in turning the souls of men into demons.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Basium raised his club, within it demons howled in pain and torment, for it wouldn't let any demon it killed return to their immortal realms. Two Seraphim settled beside the portal, swords drawn.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Factum est." the Seraphim intoned.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Not yet" Basium replied, "our battle is not done. If we mean to truly defeat the Infernal we must tear down the city of Mammon, march across the fields of Camulos and destroy the temples of Aeron. Then we will rouse Agares himself, send an army into the dust sea and remove him from his dominion."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]With that Basium marched through the gate and his army marched unquestioningly after him. After they had all passed through they destroyed the gate behind them. An entire army, a nation, walked willingly into hell and disappeared from Erebus.
TEXT.German: Bald!

TEXT.English: They had struck deeper into the Fane than any human army ever had. They had allies to watch their back, to guard the other passes. Brave Malakim champions, Balseraph mimics unpredictable but strangely reliable, and of course the heavenly armies of the Mercurians, giving grudging respect to their comrades. But the Bannor were ever at the vanguard. It was what they lived for. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Not one among this army had seen the fires of hell before, save the Commander. Those men and women who had crossed from that wretched land into world of Erebus were a dying generation. But the story of their journey survived in tales every young Bannor boy and girl learned, learned well and knew better than to doubt in the presence of their elders. The fierce dedication that had seen these people through constant war held them still enthralled, as well. This history and national character came together, leaving the Bannor knights, crusaders, and priests unflinching as they marched though the Fane, unrelenting, until even the terrible arch-angel Hyborem was overthrown. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Capria surveyed the ruins of Dis, the sprawling city Hyborem had ruled. Its dungeons were labyrinthine, and its streets filled with fiendish traps. Vile sights met the Bannor at every turn, men crucified and impaled, hanging from towers and buried up to their necks. It would be long and grim work razing the city while sanctifying those souls trapped here. But it brought some satisfaction to dismantle the apparatus of Hell on earth.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]They had not found what she came to find, but what they had accomplished was monumental, world changing. Surely more important than a personal quest to repay a priceless debt. She sighed and turned the corner, bringing the palace into view, the last refuge of the Fane. It had been pummeled by Bannor catapults, but in the ruins sat a wavering portal. The mages that accompanied her set about closing it, when from the rubble a group of hell hounds charged towards them. Capria threw herself in the way of the mages, buying time for them to get to cover. She braced for impact behind her shield, but the hound was felled from behind by a hurled spear. The other hounds rushed past her, fleeing, not attacking. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Capria lowered her shield and gasped as she saw who it was, even as she had hoped to find him. Donal Lugh, a fabled Bannor hero. Everyone who emerged from Hell all those years ago was a hero, but they all remembered the one who stayed behind, allowing them to escape with their savior Sabathiel to guide them. His hair and beard had grayed, but it was undeniably him. "Donal... I came to find you."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Donal clasped the old woman, steadying her. "Aye, little one. And I thank you for it. Surviving hell was one thing took everything I had. Emerging here, in the Infernals' strongest outpost on Erebus almost made me lose hope. Until I heard that this place was under assault. I knew my people had come to finish things, to pay the demons back for what they took."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I never got to thank you. We need you back, old friend. We have lost Sabathiel. So many have lost their way, seeking power over justice." [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Donal held her still, and the ancient warrior and leader quieted. "The next battle will come soon enough. I will be there. It is unending for us-that is why we were chosen. But we can take a rest. I think we've earned it." Behind them the portal closed with a crash, as the Bannor mages severed the Fane from Agares's vault.
TEXT.German: Bald!

TEXT.English: At first, I thought I had arrived at Amathaon's heaven. I had cheated, stolen, committed crimes beyond count, even sent Perpentach's idiot daughter to face Hell itself, and yet I had made it to paradise! Maybe the gods were rewarding me for ridding them of that spoiled brat.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]I beheld gardens, beautiful statuary, a sky that held fairy-tale clouds, and great angels dressed in pink and white. Great angels, with horns and large teeth.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The gardens, I noticed as my vision cleared, grew gulagarms, razorweed, and other, even more hellish plants. The statuary depicted not handsome men and beautiful women, but succubi and demon princes. The sky, I saw, was actually more red than pink, and the clouds were coming from an active volcano.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]This was not the hell I had imagined awaiting me, but it was hell nonetheless. One of the great demons, absurdly dressed but still terrifying, marched towards me. "Princess Keelyn wants you to dance," it said.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Princess... Keelyn?" I muttered, unable to believe what I'd heard. I was dragged to a great central hall, where upon a demonic throne made for giants was placed another throne, of mortal scale, that looked like it had come from a giant doll-house. Keelyn sat upon that throne. I could not believe it, Princess Keelyn was sitting on Hyborem's throne. I had sent her off to die, and she had overthrown the Lord of the Balors.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"You're that advisor. The one who gave me the boat."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Yes," I said. "Remember all the fun we had together..."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"You didn't like me," she said. "You were always mean to me. The only nice thing you did was give me that boat..." she leaned close and then smiled, "and that was because you thought I'd die."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]I stared, unsure how to respond to the new Lady of the Balors.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Dance," she ordered. I danced. I'm not sure how long for. She clapped and was clearly amused, but demanded I keep dancing. So I did. I kept dancing until I collapsed, unable to continue. "Don't stop! Keep dancing!" she demanded. But I couldn't. "Guards," she yelled, "he won't dance! Throw him in the Naughty Pit!"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]As I was dragged away by a Balor, I knew that the Naughty Pit was going to be far worse than dancing until collapse. The screams to which I was being dragged towards suggested that, as did the cruelly stupid grin upon the Balor's face.

For the first time the sun rose bright and shining on the Fane, not through the acrid red haze that chocked the land. The blistering sores that covered the Fane began to cool and heal. There was still a palatable feeling of loss but it was as if remembered from a dream now past.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]With the light came angels, not the barbaric ones that traveled with Basium, but gentle compassionate creatures that tended to the wounded men and spirits alike. The darkest spirits had been dragged into hell when the Throne of Hell was destroyed, but thousands still remained, those stolen unfairly by the demons or trapped between the ideals of heaven and the failure of hell.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]I walked among them, blessed souls seeking forgiveness, shared the pain with those who had carried it alone for so long. Other members of my army were the same, weary but unwilling to stop tending to these souls. It was as if we rescued a kingdom under a cruel despot, but no one had suffered as horribly as these souls had. For many it was the first kindness they had experienced in centuries.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]As I walked I saw a twisted dark tree on the wastes. Ropes hung from its limbs and it looked, as the rest of this world, to be deeply tortured. An adept sanctified the ground around the tree, turning it from charred to deep green and the tree disappeared. From where it was Talia's spirit walked toward me.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]We stared at each other in silence. I was exhausted and battle scared, she was a pale ghost, floating just above the ground in sheer robes that clung to her. She looked like a grey shadow of herself on the day we wed, strong and beautiful.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I will always love you." I said.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]She smiled slightly but there was sadness in her eyes.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The adepts spell spread and the ground below my feet began to change and grow with life as well.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I am the world now," she said, "the rivers, the trees, the mountains. Save these lands and you save me, sleep in heliotrope fields and you will dream of me. I will ever love and dream of you."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]With that she was gone and I fell to my knees and wept. But around me the land continued to change and small lavender flowers grew around me, filling the air with their scent and I knew she was nearby.

This pass is wide and lined with banners from various kingdoms. Each a trophy from an army that marched into the Fane and never returned. Distant cheers still echo through the pass, the hubris of other nations broken against the might of the Infernals.

The Balseraphs stared at the countless banners covering the pass.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Look at all of them! It's just like a carnival!" Keelyn said, giggling.[PARAGRAPH:1]Her men were more concerned; most of the banners were foreign to them, kingdoms long since passed into legend.[PARAGRAPH:1]But Keelyn cheerfully surveyed her surroundings. "Some of those banners are really pretty. I want them! All we have to do is take them! How hard can it be?"[PARAGRAPH:1]An imp in a pastel tutu materialized beside her. "Those banners are of the countless kingdoms that have been defeated here. Once mighty nations, their very names are now forgotten." The imp grinned, and with a snap of its fingers, summoned a chest. Inside there was a finely crafted Infernal banner.[PARAGRAPH:1]Keelyn examined the pass before pointing to a spot between a black banner with an old brass lantern, and a sea-blue banner with an absurd buck-toothed green fish. "I think it will look nice right there."
I rage eternal. In whatever form I am reborn I will march again against the infernal.
TEXT.German: Ich werde ewig wüten. Egal in welcher Form ich wiedergeboren werde, ich werde erneut gegen die Infernalen ins Feld ziehen.

TEXT.English: It was pride that lead me once again into hell. I only regret all of the lives it cost us.
TEXT.German: Es war der Stolz, der mich nun wieder in die Hölle geführt hat. Ich bedauere nur all die Leben, die es uns gekostet hat.

TEXT.English: The waves have now a redder glow, the hours are breathing faint and low. And when, amid no earthly moans, down, down that town shall settle hence. Hell, rising from a thousand thrones, shall do it reverence.
Back into the darkness I go. This simple fate will not be the end of my legend.
TEXT.German: Zurück in die Finsternis gehe ich. Dieses einfach Schicksal wird nicht das Ende meiner Legende sein.

TEXT.English: This place is no fun at all and the red boys have broken my toys. I will be a princess somewhere else!
TEXT.German: Dieser Ort macht überhaupt keinen Spaß und die roten Jungs haben meine Spielsachen kaputt gemacht. Ich werde woanders eine Prinzessin sein!

TEXT.English: The dead do not weep, but are wept for. Let us see who will weep for me.
TEXT.German: Die Toten weinen nicht, sondern werden beweint. Mal sehen, wer um mich weint.

TEXT.English: No one can stand against entropy, only that which consumes is eternal.
TEXT.German: Niemand kann die Entropie aufhalten. Nur das, was andere verzehrt, ist ewig.

TEXT.English: I was forged in Camulos's hell, how could lesser beings defeat me?
TEXT.German: Ich wurde in in Camulos' Hölle geschmiedet. Wie könnten mich niedere Wesen besiegen?

TEXT.English: I will miss my palace most, Erebus has never seen a greater lair of depravity and cruelty then that which I designed.
TEXT.German: Ich werde meinen Palast am meisten vermissen. Erebus ist niemals Zeuge eines großartigeren Monuments der Verderbtheit und der Grausamkeit geworden als jenes, das ich entworfen habe.

TEXT.English: You purge this desire from me only to take it up yourself. No man turns away from power, it is the chain Agares binds us with. Where one demon lord falls another rises.
TEXT.German: Ihr nehmt mir dieses Verlangen nur, um es Euch selbst zu eigen zu machen. Niemand wendet sich von der Macht ab. Es ist die Leine, mit der uns Agares an sich bindet. Wo ein Dämonenfürst versagt, steigt ein anderer auf.

TEXT.English: Talia... I was too weak to avenge you.
TEXT.German: Talia... ich war zu schwach, um Euch zu rächen.

TEXT.English: Description: Take your army into the Fane of Lessers and destroy the throne of hell.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Reward: Completing this scenario reduces the Infernal's power in all the other scenarios[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Requires: Successful completion of the Radiant Guard and Wages of Sin scenarios.
TEXT.German: Beschreibung: Führt Eure Armee in den Tempel der Unbedeutenden und zerstört den Höllenthron.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Besondere Regeln: Die Auswirkungen auf den Armageddonzähler werden verdoppelt, aber durch die Zerstörung von Nekrototems sinkt er auch wieder.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Belohnung: Bei erfolgreichem Abschluss dieses Szenarios verringert sich die Stärke der Infernalen in allen anderen Szenarien.

TEXT.English: This pass looks to be abandoned. As your army moves through a few spirits can be seen drifting between the various alcoves set in the high walls. They are hiding here from their demonic masters, and angered that your passing may draw attention to them.
TEXT.German: Dieser Pass scheint verlassen zu sein. Als Eure Armee ihn passiert, bemerkt Ihr einige Geister, die zwischen den verschiedenen Nischen der Steilwand hin und her schweben. Sie verstecken sich hier vor ihren dämonischen Herren und sind erzürnt, dass Eure Durchquerung vielleicht die Aufmerksamkeit auf sie lenken wird.

TEXT.English: The souls hiding in this pass are cowards hiding from their demonic lords. At first they mistook Keelyn for a succubus queen and fled. Keelyn, curious to see what these timid shapes bounding away in terror are, ordered a few of them captured. Upon capture, one of the souls struggled for words.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Your malevolence," he began, "we are of no interest to you... let us be, we are unworthy."[PARAGRAPH:1]"I will," Keelyn responded, "if you agree to be good little spirits and serve me."[PARAGRAPH:1]"We have always served you and your masters, lady..." one of the souls stammered.[PARAGRAPH:1]Keelyn took out a runic knife and sliced the spirit, which screamed in pain.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I don't have a master," Keelyn said, "and soon these lands will be mine. I don't have to follow anyone's rules."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Very well, than we kneel before you... as... the new Queen of the Fane of the Lessers, glorious mistress of..." another slice, another scream of pain.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I prefer Princess of the Fane. Queens are old and tired, princesses are young and pretty. And forget the Lessers, it doesn't sound very impressive."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Yes, yes... whatever you wish... you are the Princess of the Fane, your beauty is beyond words, your power is beyond our mere comprehension, just please don't hurt us."[PARAGRAPH:1]"I won't, if you do one thing."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Why, anything, your grace!"[PARAGRAPH:1]"I'm bored. Sing me a song." With a casual spin of a dagger, she adds, "and make sure it's a good one."
Men are trapped beyond the veil of fire. Your army is able put out the fire long enough for the men to pass through.
Defeat the %d1 remaining Demon Lords
TEXT.German: Besiegt [NUM1:den:die] verbleibenden %d1 [NUM1:Dämonenfürst:Dämonenfürsten]

TEXT.English: I am forever held within the ravages of war. I am the last warrior of the Godswar and I will carry this battle across Erebus, through every civilization of men, into the stronghold of the Infernals and into hell itself if needed.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]But I am no fool. Men are weak, painfully short sighted and prone to betrayal for meaningless reasons. They trade their virtue for dirt, for skirt, or far less. Despite their weakness Erebus is their world, so the compact has decreed. And where the death of my angels is a loss forever, the tides of men seem endless. What need is there for immortality when the generations pouring forth from their dirty cities come faster than they can be extinguished, and each more pallid and anemic than the last. But this war cannot be won without them.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]There seems some small hope in this generation. Glorious Sabathiel has guided the Bannor through hell itself, and these men survived the trip. Now they mean to sail to the Fane of Lessers, to rescue a companion thought long lost. To walk an army into Hyborem's lands and take what they wish.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]And even spineless Lugus has a High Priest among the Malakim willing to stand against the demons. He sails for the Fane as well, but for revenge. It is a lesser reason than the salvation of the world, but it will do. It amazes me how men can become so passionate about the plight of one soul but so blatantly ignore the rest.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Regardless I have long watched the Fane, as a shepherd watches the forest that houses the wolves. With two strong armies moving against the demons the Mercurians will join. These men I command have lost what they love to the Infernal. They fight on raw passion, and will serve me well in life, and continue to serve as angels if they fall on the battlefield. The Bannor and the Malakim may only distract the Infernals, but we have the opportunity we seek. The war set into motion at the signing of the compact reaches its conclusion here. I will lead an army into the Fane of Lessers, I will purge the Infernal from Erebus.

Capria screamed. It took her a few seconds to adjust to the dim light of her bedchamber. She was alone but her dreams still echoed through her mind. Visions of demons in that final escape from hell, of the closing portal and Donal Lugh beyond it trapped forever in hell. She could still hear him calling for her.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Guards rushed into the room, weapons at the ready.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Lady Capria, are you alright?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]She steadied herself, she was still out of breath from the dream and covered in sweat. But these men believed her to be almost as inhuman as Sabathiel himself, and she wouldn't let them see her weak.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Of course I'm fine, return to your post."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The guards apologized and left. Capria lay back down but she was unable to escape the dream. Back asleep she saw Donal again, but this time there was no portal. He was in a land defiled but it was not hell, surrounded by vast mountains but here on Erebus.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In the morning she knew what she had to do. That Donal Lugh, who was trapped in hell so long ago, was still alive. She quickly dressed and headed to the shipyard, she needed a galleon and a few troops to rescue him. And woe to any demon who stood between her and the Bannor's greatest hero.

"I'm getting a new pet," Princess Keelyn happily announced one day. "Don't worry, Chuckles, you're still my favorite. But this new one is going to be really fun!" She bounded eagerly down the steps to her summoning chamber.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Her newest circle was the largest one I'd ever seen. Normally, she summons imps, other balors, and occasionally elementals. But this new circle was bigger even than the one she summoned me with. I remember it clearly; I'd been so full of anger, so hateful then. But Keelyn taught me to be happy. And I was happy. And now I served her, since she was nice to me as long as I wasn't naughty.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]I examined the runes, they read "Hyborem." I'd heard that name... I thought back. It was hard, remembering the bad days. But the name... scared me for some reason.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Who are you summoning, Mistress?" I asked.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I was reading this book my from my daddy's library, and it said the biggest demon of them all was Hyborem. So I'm going to summon him."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Hyborem. Why did that seem like a bad idea? All the other demons Keelyn summoned learned to love their new master. But for some reason, I was worried. Hyborem must have been scary in the bad days, even scarier than I was. Keelyn snapped her fingers, and her puppets jolted into motion. They began dancing as Keelyn chanted the words of the summoning spell. And the Lord of the Balors appeared before us.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Hyborem was big. Huge. He barely fit in the summoning circle. He roared as he struggled against the bounds.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Who dares call me from my palace? What mortal is arrogant enough to..." he looked down. "What have we here, a little girl, mixed blood of the insane and the profane? This is a fine sacrifice. Release me, and I'll take my sacrifice and decide your fate. Your agony will only be temporary, and I'll let you live for now. Just remember... next time you summon me, ask, do not command." Hyborem looked at me and rose to his full height. "You! Throw me my sacrifice, and then reveal this foolish mage."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Why are you giving me orders?" I asked.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Hyborem stared. He ragged against the circle. The bonds constrained him, a fact that only infuriated Hyborem more. "You dare question your lord?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"No," I said. "I obey Princess Keelyn."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Hyborem looked at me, noticed the pink bow around my horns, and then glanced at the matching bow in Keelyn's hair. He brought his face as close to Keelyn as the summoning circle would allow. "Pedicabo ego vos et irrumabo. In the history of Erebus, none have been as arrogant as you. You take my servants from me and summon me like some common imp?" Again, Hyborem thrashed at the circle. But Princess Keelyn's circles held. He growled. "There is no agony in hell horrible enough for you. I will suffocate you on the excrement of Abyssus, you will spend ages in a pit filled with the screaming aborted fetuses of depraved whores. I will devise a new punishment, just for you... and that treasonous idiot." With that, Hyborem muttered a spell and vanished.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Where'd he go?" Keelyn asked.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]I looked back into my memories. "The Fane of Lessers," I answered, though the words meant nothing to me.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Keelyn leaped up the stairs before running into a pair of Perpentach's advisors.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"My princess," one said, "we weren't expecting you to be done so soon."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"My new pet got away," Keelyn said, "and I need to go punish him."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Where'd he go?" asked the other advisor.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"The Fane of Lessers. His name is Hyborem and he has a very naughty mouth."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The advisors stared at each other. "You would chase Hyborem to his own realm because... he wouldn't play tea party?! You could get killed..." the other advisor elbowed the speaker in the stomach. They glanced conspiratorially at each other. They briefly spoke in whispers, before saying, with suspicious smiles, "we'll arrange for a galleon and some... volunteers... to help you." As we left, I could have sworn I heard one mutter, "what if she succeeds?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The other snickered. "Don't worry. She's as good as dead."

I forgave her, but she couldn't forgive herself.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]It wasn't unusual for Talia to worship at dusk. She revered it as I revered the dawn. She said that as the world slept the spirits came out to wander across it and often slipped into bed late, warm from the magic she channeled and smelling of the heliotrope flowers that covered the shrine she kept in the temple. She was beautiful and I loved her.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]I arose one morning to find that she never came to bed. It was three days since she told me about her affair and through many tears, both in anger and sadness, we worked through it. I promised myself that I would forget what she had done, that I would trust her again. But in seeing the empty bed my mind leapt to suspicions.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]I found her body laying before her shrine. She had expended her spirit entirely in casting, let her life flow from her for no reason other than to give it up. There was a short note with her, it read simply "I'm sorry."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]There was no salvation for her. And I shed tears once again at the altar of Lugus. Angels tended to me, brilliant compassionate beings who cried along with me. In time we divined Talia's last hours. She hated the pain she caused me and prayed for some relief. But the druidic spirits consoled only time and patience to heal those wounds. Another voice had offered a more immediate solution.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]That was the demoness Lethe, Queen of Sorrow. She whispered to Talia as she had thousands before. Bade her to forget her life and enter the abyss to escape her pain. And Talia followed it, killing herself at the shrine, believing somehow that she was making it easier for me.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Now we sail towards an idyllic beach. The tides beat regularly against white sand that rises smoothly to a thick ridge of mountain. It's hard to believe that the Fane of Lessers, the place where Agares dwelt during the Godswar, where the souls of the damned are drawn, lies beyond those mountains.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]This may be madness. To assault the stronghold of evil with only those few volunteers that could join me on this galleon. But Lethe is somewhere within that twisted hellish terrain, and I will make sure that her voice, and those the demon lords that dwell with her, will be removed from Erebus.
The faith in Lugus, god of the dawn, spreads through your people. They rally to your flag and offer their aide in your war against the Infernal.
TEXT.German: Der Glaube an Lugus, den Gott der Morgendämmerung, verbreitet sich unter Eurem Volk. Sie versammeln sich unter Eurem Banner und bieten Euch ihre Unterstützung für Euren Krieg gegen die Infernalen an.

TEXT.English: You are not alone. The Order sends soldiers to aide you. They are steadfast and loyal troops.
TEXT.German: Ihr seid nicht allein. Die Weisung entsendet Soldaten zu Eurer Unterstützung. Es sind unerschütterliche und loyale Truppen.

TEXT.English: A priest and a pair of brine-covered men play in the ocean waves. Curiosity brings them to your city where they tell strange stories and you decide to let them stay, even if they do smell funny.
TEXT.German: Ein Priester und zwei salzverkrustete Männer spielen in der Meeresbrandung. Die Neugier treibt sie in Eure Stadt, wo sie merkwürdige Geschichten erzählen. Ihr entscheidet sie bleiben zu lassen, obwohl sie komisch riechen.

TEXT.English: This pass is used by souls that committed suicide. The walls on each side are steep with sharp ledges high above the floor of the pass. At night the souls unwilling to enter the Fane can be seen here reliving their last moments of life. Many souls hang from the ledges, still twitching in eternal death throes.[PARAGRAPH:1]A girl in a pale dress jumps from a ledge screaming, hitting the ground near your men only to reform again on the ledge and repeat the action. A mother, her face swollen with bruises, drinks from a vial then falls asleep surrounded by the cries of her children.

The Balseraph soldiers stood entranced by the singing of the demon Lethe; a song of sorrows and cruelties of the mortal world, and the painlessness of oblivion. Some soldiers felt an urge to obey her calls, others only a creeping dread. But as terrible as it was, it was also hauntingly beautiful.[PARAGRAPH:1]Keelyn, apparently immune to the enchantment of demons, only said, "she sings nice. Even better than my little birdy. Bring her to me, so she can be my new little birdy. Have a big cage made, she won't fit in the old one."[PARAGRAPH:1]The most strong-willed soldiers were snapped out of their awe by Keelyn's command, and the fear of being fed to Balors. They began preparing for their princess's wish. The wisest began looking for metal for a cage, excusing themselves from the potential battle. To deal with those that remained entranced, Keelyn placed a curse upon one of the them. So wrapped up in the song, he hardly noticed the spell... until Keelyn activated the curse, sending unimaginable pain through his body, while leaving him unable to die, or even slip into unconsciousness. He screamed, drowning out the siren's song and breaking the trance.

This pass is used by souls that committed suicide. The walls on each side are steep with sharp ledges high above the floor of the pass. At night the souls unwilling to enter the Fane can be seen here reliving their last moments of life. Many souls hang from the ledges, still twitching in eternal death throes.[PARAGRAPH:1]A girl in a pale dress jumps from a ledge screaming, hitting the ground near your men only to reform again on the ledge and repeat the action. A mother, her face swollen with bruises, drinks from a vial then falls asleep surrounded by the cries of her children.[PARAGRAPH:1]You wonder if Talia came through this pass. Your men pray for each spirit they find, but their prayers bring no relief. Lethe's whispers have ruined more lives than your own.
Mulcarn Reborn
TEXT.German: Mulcarns Wiedergeburt

TEXT.English: Even the pathetic tinkers rallied a more effective assault than you. Now that I am truly reborn you will make no more progress in this age.

Commander Achare led the hunters personally; he wanted to see the lay of the land of a site that would almost certainly be a battlefield in the coming weeks. He didn't know that they were walking into a Doviello ambush-but that wouldn't have stopped him. Life was struggle, and Bannor commanders don't survive it by leading from the rear. They survive it by being very good fighters as well as leaders.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]And by being lucky when they need to be. A horde of Sons of Asena sprang from the woods, icy winds at their back. The Bannor hunters formed ranks quickly, sending in their wolves to skirmish as they fired at their attackers with short bows. Doviello men were not deterred by charging wolves, and the Bannor prepared to go down fighting.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]But the Doviello stopped their charge, turned and faced new threat from behind them. Emerging from the darkness came Moroi, the savage foot soldiers of the Calabim. The Doviello were quickly dispatched, as the Moroi matched their ferocity with surprise.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Bannor commander kept his men alert. Though they hadn't had a reason to enter Calabim lands, he wasn't ignorant of the world. The Calabim were monsters, and he would happily lead a crusade into their cities if ordered. Worse, they had sided with the Sheaim and Infernal in Tempus Mor, the very battle he had been training to join when Auric led his armies into Torrolerial and sacked the great city, seemingly slaying the Bannor leader Sabathiel in the process. But no blood had been spilled between them yet, and he awaited some announcement from their saviors.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Men of the Bannor," the Calabim commander began, emerging from the ranks of his soldiers, then stopped. "Well. Hello father."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Samatheon Achare froze, seeing his fugitive son Decius before him. "So. This is where you ended up. I must admit that after we discovered your innocence I hoped you were still alive... but I think death would have been preferable to this."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Innocent?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Yes. Well, innocent of witchcraft and blasphemy. Guilty of knocking out three of your father's teeth with an idol. It was planted by Arret, Rosier's uncle. We found out he was a necromancer and veil disciple during the sack of Torrolerial. It seems he framed you to throw off suspicion aroused by Rosier's betrayal."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"So it took the near destruction of your beloved nation to show you the error of your ways."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"What? We face a setback, but our whole history has been one pitched battle, Decius, you know that. I do not apologize for what transpired between us. You should have come along and faced trial rather than assault me and flee. How were we to take that other than as a confirmation of guilt?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"A trial would have found me innocent?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Probably. Possibly not. Sometimes innocents suffer; this is a consequence of the imperfection of our world. Law and order are the only way for society to function, and guilty must pay, even if occasionally an innocent is blamed."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius said, "Blood means nothing to you?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I've shed tears for you already Decius, but I will weaken my civilization to favor my own children. Why are you here? To strike your revenge while we are weakened?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Hardly. From what I hear, the last ice age was rather hard on the Calabim who make up my imperial troops. I aim to prevent the next one."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Commander Achare sheathed his sword and turned his back. "Then we are allies, for a time."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"And after?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Most certainly not. You lead a band of murderers, and bring dishonor on your family. I hope you fall in battle, son, there is little other hope of your redemption now."

Commander Achare led the hunters personally; he wanted to see the lay of the land of a site that would almost certainly be a battlefield in the coming weeks. He didn't know that they were walking into a Doviello ambush-but that wouldn't have stopped him. Life was struggle, and Bannor commanders don't survive it by leading from the rear. They survive it by being very good fighters as well as leaders.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]And by being lucky when they need to be. A horde of Sons of Asena sprang from the woods, icy winds at their back. The Bannor hunters formed ranks quickly, sending in their wolves to skirmish as they fired at their attackers with short bows. Doviello men were not deterred by charging wolves, and the Bannor prepared to go down fighting.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]But the Doviello stopped their charge, turned and faced a new threat from behind them. Malakim warriors, dressed for the arctic battle in lion fur coats, descended upon the Doviello. The wild men turn on them in a rage, but the newcomers to the Aquillo tundra hold their lines, showing a discipline matching the Bannor's. The Bannor commander ordered his hunters to strike, and the Doviello ambush is turned to a rout, with Malakim cavalry chasing down the survivors.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Commander Samatheon Achare stepped forward to offer thanks to their saviors, but stopped when he saw who stepped out to greet him. "I see the Bannor sent their best to stop the end of the world."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Decius? By Junil, I had feared you dead."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"No. I am not dead. I have traveled the ends of the earth to seek refuge from false accusations, but I live and am better for it."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"False accusations. Not false, for I accused you in good faith, but wrong nonetheless. Arret, Rosier's uncle, was revealed a necromancer in the sacking of Torrolerial. But the evidence before my eyes could not be ignored. A man cannot show favoritism to his own kin over the rule of law-that is the way of anarchy and tyranny. I have long grieved for what transpired between us-that you would see your own father as your persecutor, that the promise your life showed should be wasted."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I understand. I cannot say I regret my flee from justice, but I absolve you. The Bannor notion of righteousness is lacking-incomplete. But you served me well in my youth, and gave me a love of goodness and honor that I was able to preserve, despite everything. My time with the Malakim, these men who now follow me, allowed me to grasp the complete vision-justice paired with redemption and reconciliation. It will be good to speak of these matters further with you, should we survive this war with Auric."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Yes. Although it would be best for you to avoid the Bannor lands. You are not a heretic, but you did strike your commanding officer."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Uncompromising even as the fate of the world hangs in the balance?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"How else do you think we survived this long, my son? I am glad to see you in a good place. But do not expect us to change, not so fast. Perhaps as we work with your Overcouncil, we can test these new ideas that Varn Gosam is teaching. Well. We must report back, and lady Capria will be pleased to hear that you are here supporting us. Be well."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"And you," Decius replied, before turning back to his army.
You have tamed the spirit that ruled me; though you bring me death I thank you for it.
TEXT.German: Ihr habt den Geist bezähmt, der mich beherrscht hat. Obwohl Ihr mir den Tod bringt, danke ich Euch dafür.

TEXT.English: In life or death I only wait for Auric's rebirth as the God of Winter. You cannot change that.
TEXT.German: Egal ob lebendig oder tot, ich warte nur auf Aurics Geburt als Gott des Winters. Das könnt Ihr nicht verhindern.

TEXT.English: The Bannor will stand until the end, but we have reached that point.
TEXT.German: Die Bannor werden bis zum Ende ausharren, doch dieser Punkt ist nun erreicht.

TEXT.English: Let my army fall, I'll raise another from the pits of Prespur.
TEXT.German: Lasst meine Armee untergehen. Ich werden eine andere in den Gruben von Prespur ausheben.

TEXT.English: We are entering the night; the Malakim have fallen.
TEXT.German: Wir gehen ins Dunkel. Die Malakim sind besiegt.

TEXT.English: The white dragon awaits, I am only sorry I won't see it come for you.
TEXT.German: Der Weiße Drache harrt Eurer. Ich bin nur traurig, dass ich nicht sehen werde, wie er Euch heimsucht.

TEXT.English: He is too strong, I cannot go on my friend.
TEXT.German: Er ist zu stark. Ich kann Euch nicht weiter begleiten, mein Freund.

TEXT.English: The Doviello are done, there is no place for them in this age.
TEXT.German: Die Doviello sind besiegt. Für sie gibt es in diesem Zeitalter keinen Platz mehr.

TEXT.English: Are all the Hippus to fall to one man? You must avenge Tasunke without me.
TEXT.German: Werden alle Hippus einem Mann zum Opfer fallen? Ihr müsst Tasunke ohne mich rächen.

TEXT.English: Rage against me as you will, the winter will not end.
TEXT.German: Wettere gegen mich solange du willst. Der Winter wird nicht enden.

TEXT.English: The summer queen enslaved me. This was never the path I wanted.
TEXT.German: Die Sommerkönigin hat mich versklavt. Dies war niemals der Weg, den ich gehen wollte.

TEXT.English: Description: Auric means to ascend to godhood. If Erebus is to be saved from another Age of Ice you must stop him.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Special Rules: You will be placed in control of the weakest member of your team. You must coordinate your unit's forces together, because if any member falls you will likely be in control of them when they do.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Requires: Completion of The Black Tower, The Cult, and Against the Grey.
TEXT.German: Beschreibung: Auric hat vor, zu einer Gottheit aufzusteigen. Wenn Ihr Erebus vor einem weiteren Zeitalter des Eises bewahren wollt, müsst Ihr ihn aufhalten.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Besondere Regeln: Ihr werdet die Führung Eures schwächsten Verbündeten übernehmen. Ihr müsst die Kräfte eurer Einheiten zusammen koordinieren, denn, falls einer der Verbündeten untergeht, werdet Ihr wahrscheinlich gerade dessen Führung inne haben.

TEXT.English: Switching leader in %d1 turns
TEXT.German: Wechsel der Zivilisation in %d1 [NUM1:Runde:Runden]

TEXT.English: Across the Aquilo Tundra leaders sat in war rooms staring at scattered maps on long tables. Rhoanna was determined and anxious, pushing her captains to make immediate attacks against the Doviello and the Illians before they prepare their defenses. Capria, always aware of the threat of overextension, advised her captains to carefully guard their foothold on Auric's island and expand slowly. Falamar landed offshore from the tundra so that he could train units and launch attacks without fear of direct retaliation.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Their enemies were no different. Riuros, Anagantios and Dumannios had little concern for the meager boats that landed on their shores, but Lucian took the invasion more seriously and he was glad to see Mahala arrive with more soldiers.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"You have done well." Mahala said, "News of your victories has drawn many Doviello from the wastes looking for blood, or to be nearby when Auric's rewards are handed out."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]She paused, looking through one of her supply chests for a belt of short knives, before asking, "Is it true that Cassiel is dead?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Yes. Midgar burned to the ground and their king was sacrificed in one of Auric's rituals."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"If the stories are true then you and the Illian commanders are the first to witness the death of an archangel. What was it like?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Lucian shifted uncomfortably, "He died poorly, chained like a dog and serving his enemies' purpose in his death instead of his own."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Let us hope that we fare better than he did." Mahala said half-joking, but Lucian remained quiet.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I have been to Auric's capital." Mahala said, switching the subject, "I have seen the pillar of light from his ritual, felt the welling power of a god soon to be born, and watched the dragon circling the city. It is hard to imagine that Auric will not succeed, and if he does we are best to be on his side when he does. Are these your thoughts as well?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Lucian considered. He was a powerful man among the Doviello, strong, clever and brutal. Although very capable, there were thousands of men like him across Erebus. Those born among the Lanun became pirates living on the edges of their society, their lawlessness made them feared by victims and fellow pirates alike, and outcasts from their own society. Among the Bannor men like him were quickly imprisoned or sent to the gallows. Success isn't a result of talent alone, but of your talents value in your society. One society's general is another's criminal, one society's artist is another's madman.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Yes." Lucian answered, "The Doviello cannot live in this world, we must return to an older one if we are to flourish."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Very well, we have only to scatter these fledgling armies until Auric completes his ritual. Then we will return to our more primal world."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Falamar never imagined himself as a commander of anything but his own ship. For him supply lines were something to be intercepted and pilfered, not guarded. A treasury should finance nights of excess, not a growing war.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"We have delivered Rhoanna to the war." Amergin offered.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]It was as close as loyal Amergin ever came to questioning his captain, the implication that they had earned some rest after their defeat of Tebryn in the Dead Lands.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Yes, I suppose we have. But if she defeats Auric, what sort of victory will it be, and how can we miss the opportunity to participate in such legends." Falamar answered.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"We have gone from hunting wolves to demonic armies, played parts in the Momus's crazed game and watched our brothers reborn as undead before our eyes. These may be legends, but there is little glory in them."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Falamar nodded. "And if she fails, what then? What sort of world will it be? Can even the Black Wind sail fast enough to escape the grip of eternal winter, or will we all share Malus's fate?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"No." Amergin answered, "The Lanun could not survive in that world, we must save this one."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Amergin paused before adding, "Forgive my ramblings, I am ever at your side. I have been away from my rum for too long, and it muddies my thoughts."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Falamar smiled, placing two cups on the table and pulling a small cast from beneath it. He poured them both drinks as he smiled adding, "Or perhaps your time sober has made your thoughts too clear, that is never a good trait for a soldier."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]They laughed, toasted and drank into the night, sharing stories and planning for the hard days ahead.
TEXT.German: Bald!

TEXT.English: The %s1_civ need your help. You must lead them against Auric.
TEXT.German: Die %s1_civ benötigen Eure Hilfe. Ihr müsst sie gegen Auric in den Kampf führen.

TEXT.English: The Illian capital is a ring of military buildings around a massive pillar of pale white light. An intense cold radiates out from the light, frosting exposed flesh and reaching through the thickest furs to chill bones and freeze the breath. The Illian defenders are quickly cut down, they refuse to retreat into the pillar, seeming more afraid of what lies within it than the advancing army.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The capture of the city doesn't stop the ritual. Everyone can feel the welling power, the proximity to a powerful, divine, malevolent force. A few archers lob arrows into the pillar without effect, fire spells dissipate uselessly.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius sticks the Nether Blade through the veil of light, when he withdraws it is cold to the touch by undamaged. He sheaths the sword and goes back to where the commanders discuss a plan. With no good options Rhoanna breaks the stalemate. In one quick motion she pulls the Nether Blade from Decius's belt and charges into the light.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Stepping into the pillar is like entering a new world. Primal winds howl and the light is replaced with the white of a raging blizzard. Everything is white, and what was the flat ground of the city center is replaced with a steep mountainous slope.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Rhoanna crawls forward, she can feel the cold air tearing through her, like she has swallowed knives. Through the sleet of white she gets occasional glimpses of a steep mountainside behind her, and beyond a vast black swamp. Other howls give evidence that she isn't alone on the slope but she keeps climbing.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Her arms and legs go past cold, go past numb and start feeling warm. She is only sure she still drags the Nether Blade along with her because she can see it in her hand. Dreams begin to overcome her, the soft grasslands of her home, the feel of a saddle beneath her, the warmth of Falamar's bed.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]She stops moving, seeing another world around her as a frost giant lumbers out of the storm. Unwilling to smash such a nice meal he picks up the freezing Rhoanna in one giant fist. She curls up in his hand, then in a flash of clarity realizes where she is and stabs out with the sword, piercing his neck and sending the giant falling backwards. He is dead before he hits the ground. Determined, Rhoanna pulls the sword out of his neck and once again begins her ascent.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]It is only a few hundred feet, but it feels like miles. By the time she can see the peak her arms and legs refuse to obey her. But she can see Auric standing on the peak unaffected by the raging blizzard around him. Around him, around the mountain itself, a god rages.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Auric looks at the woman staggering towards him. He is transcendent, a man at his most powerful, almost a god against a woman who is too stubborn to die. He smiles.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]For Tasunke she thinks, she tries to scream it but she can't muster the breath to force the words through frozen lips. She promises her body, one last rush and she will allow it to die, just another 20 feet.
